msItem.title: List of contents
msItem.note: The list was added to the manuscript not long after the main text was completed
(See David Rundle, ‘The Circulation and Use of Humanist "Miscellanies" in England', Mélanges de l’École française de Rome—Moyen Âge 228 [2016], p. 11)

msItem.author: Pietro del Monte
msItem.title: De uitiorum inter se differentia
msItem.rubric: Petrus de Monte ad illustrissimum principem Ducem Gloucestrie de virtutum & viciorum inter se differencia
msItem.note: The three books are: Book 1 (pp. 3-28); Book 2 (pp. 29-54); Book 3 (pp. 54-83)
Dedicated to Humfrey, Duke of Gloucester (1438)

msItem.author: Leonardo Bruni
msItem.title: Oratio in hypocritas
msItem.rubric: Invectiva leonardi Aretini contra ypocritas incipit
msItem.incipit: Ex omni genere hominum quos varij
msItem.explicit: In vicia autem aliena non curiosus sis sed in tua. Explicit

msItem.author: Xenophon
msItem.title: Hiero
msItem.rubric: Leonardi Arretini prefacio in librum zenophontis incipit qui Tirannus dicitur
msItem.incipit: Zenophontis philosophi liber qui dicitur tyrannus incipit feliciter
msItem.explicit: felix enim cum sis nemo tibi invidebit. Explicit liber

msItem.author: Lapo da Castiglionchio
msItem.title: Comparatio Studiorum et Rei Militaris
msItem.rubric: Ad illustrissimum principem Humfridum ducem Glowcestrie et comitem penbrothie [then in different ink] lapicastellinculi comparatio studiorum & rei militaris
msItem.explicit: atque effugere incommoda potuerunt. Explicit liber
msItem.note: Dedicated to Humfrey, Duke of Gloucester (1437)

msItem.author: Basil of Caesarea
msItem.title: Ad adolescentes
msItem.rubric: Leonardi Arretini prefacio ad colucium salutatum in librum magni Basilij
msItem.incipit: Magni basilij ad Iuvenes religiosos quibus studijs opera danda sit
msItem.explicit: nunc recta consilia aspernantes. Explicit liber
msItem.note: Preceded by the preface of Leonardo Bruni, the translator, to Colucius Salutatus

msItem.author: Isocrates
msItem.title: Ad Demonicum [Latin]
msItem.rubric: Isocratis oracio ad demonicum incipit feliciter

msItem.author: Isocrates
msItem.title: Nicocles [Latin]
msItem.explicit: sed tantum fide iusticiaque conficere. Explicit

msItem.author: Isocrates
msItem.title: Ad Nicoclem [Latin]
msItem.rubric: Isocratis oratio ad nicoclem de regno incipit
msItem.explicit: sed maiora ac digniora efficies. Explicit

msItem.author: Isocrates
msItem.title: Nicocles [Latin]
msItem.rubric: Guarini veronesis in orationem isocratis Qua in subditos regem instituit ad principem leonellum estensem epistola incipit
msItem.explicit: Universa licebit hec licebit absolvere. Explicit

msItem.author: Guarino da Verona
msItem.title: De assentatoris et amici differencia
msItem.rubric: Guarini Veronensis ad illustrem principem dominum leonellum Estensem de assentatoris & amici differencia ex plutharcho liber incipit
msItem.note: An adaptation, not simply a translation, of Plutarch's Quomodo adulator ab amico internoscatur

msItem.title: Glossary
msItem.incipit: Auriolor laris lari id est divinare
msItem.explicit: Venum ibunt id est vendentur. Pestes tidis proprium nomen
msItem.note: A glossary of the difficult words found in this volume, providing principal parts for verbs, and gender and declension for nouns
(See Rundle, 'Humanist Eloquence Among the Barbarians in Fifteenth-century England’, in Britannia Latina, ed. by Charles Burnett and Nicholas Mann [London: Warburg Insitute, 2005], pp. 76-77)

supportDesc.extent:
v (first paper, rest parchment) + 199 + ii (one parchment, other paper). Pagination (partly in pen [s. xvii], partly in pencil [s. xx]): i-x, 1-241. There are two errors in this pagination: first, there is no p. 11; second, the numbers 157-158 are repeated. So, from p. 12 to p. 158, page numbers are one greater than they should be, while from p. 158 bis to the end, they are one lower than is correct. Throughout, the corrected pagination proposed by David Rundle is used
236 163
supportDesc.collation: 1-912, 1012 wanting 3 (after p. 220 recte). Catchwords. Evidence of leaf signatures at pp. 121, 127, 129 and 131
supportDesc.condition: A square hole has been cut out of p. x, possibly to remove the name of an early owner or the name of the intended recipient

layoutDesc.layout:
30 long lines, fully ruled and pricked. Written space:
150 100

handDesc.handNote: Written in a Gothic book-hand by a scribe who is known to have worked with Henry Mere on MS. Bodl. 281 and who collaborated with a group of scribes in the 1460s (including William Salomon) on Oxford, Exeter College, MSS. 51-68. The scribe's handwriting is similar to Mere’s: g has an upright stem which ascends pronouncedly above the horizontal stroke; a has two compartments; and i at the beginning of a word is often written as if it were a majuscule. The punctuation is very noticeable and there is a light, but clear, diagonal stroke dotting i. The scribe used black ink, with titles in red, and wrote many of the notes in the margin. David Rundle identifies the scribe as William Osborne (see Rundle, 'The Playpen: Reform, Experimentation and the Memory of Humfrey, Duke of Gloucester in the Registry of the University of Oxford', in Books and Bookmen in Early Modern Britain: Essays Presented to James P. Carley, ed. by James Willoughby and Jeremy Catto [Toronto: Pontifical Institute of Mediaeval Studies, 2018], pp. 28 and 37)

The contents list on p. x is likely to have been added to the manuscript not long after the main text was completed. Rundle argues that the scribe who added the contents list was John Manyngham (Rundle, 'The Playpen' [2018], pp. 38-39) and that Manyngham also wrote the word 'EXPLICIT' on p. 93 and was responsible for the corrections on pp. 9, 14, 6, 20, 39, 49, 91, 107, ?108, ?123, 131, 175, 189, 194, 204 and 206. The contents list is written in a script that experiments with Humanist letter-forms (note also the unusual g written with one stroke and looking something like a q written diagonally)
Another hand, in a small, lightly written Gothic script, corrected the text (e.g. pp. 119, 120, 121, 131, 203, etc.)

Albinia de la Mare suggested that one of the annotators in this manuscript also wrote a note on fol. 113 of MS. Selden Supra 22 (Duke Humfrey’s Library & the Divinity School 1488–1988 [Oxford, 1988], p. 66). Building on this identification, Rundle observes that a note on p. 122 of MS. Auct. F. 5. 26 may well be in the same hand, and that the maniculae with narrow cuffs and bases drawn with a jagged line on pp. 36, 98, 126, 191 in MS. Auct. F. 5. 26 resemble those found in MS. Selden Supra 22 on fols 113 and 156. Similarly, a flower nota-mark in MS. Auct. F. 5. 26 (p. 125; cf. pp. 37 and 131) is comparable to that on fol. 17 of MS. Selden Supra 22

Other annotations include those in a large 16th-century hand in black ink concentrated in Item 1, marking subject-matter (pp. 9, 12, 14, 18, 19, 30, 32, 33, 34, 36, 42, 51). At the front of the volume (pp. v-vii), another mid-16th century hand adds notes mainly on Item 1, offering quotations that follow the work’s line of argument

decoDesc.decoNote: Good initials, e.g. p. 1 and p. 116

Decorative initials appear on pp. 1, 84, 115, 178, 187 and 201, each adorned with half-borders comprising pen-strokes that are coloured with green and small balls of gold, creating a pattern of ‘fir cones’. This is the work of the English illuminator of MS. Bodl. 283 and British Library, MS. Royal 18 D. ii, fol. 6 (see Kathleen L. Scott, The Mirroure of the Worlde [Oxford, 1980], pp. 34-40) and Kathleen L. Scott, Late Gothic Manuscripts, 1390-1490 [London, 1996], Pl. 387). This style has been related to the ‘Abingdon Missal Border Master’ who was London-based but also worked in Oxford in the 1450s and the 1460s (Rundle, 'The Playpen' [2018], p. 27)

physDesc.additions: There are marginalia and various nota-marks written by more than ten 15th- and 16th-century users of the volume

binding.p: Early plain parchment binding with remnants of four pieces of string which were used to tie the volume closed

origin.note: One of three extant copies of a Humanist miscellany compiled in Oxford in the 1440s. The other copies are Cambridge, University Library, MS. Ll. i. 7 and London, Lambeth Palace Library, MS. 341. Rundle has dubbed these three manuscripts the ‘Virtue and Vice’ miscellany because of an error (or deliberate change) that they share in the title of Item 1 ('De virtutum et vitiorum differentia' instead of 'De vitiorum inter se differentia'). The texts were largely (but perhaps not entirely) transcribed from manuscripts donated to the university by Humfrey, Duke of Gloucester. Each of these manuscripts presents the same set of ten texts – although the order is slightly different in CUL, MS. Ll. i. 7 – and, with the exception of Item 1, the texts were all composed in Italy.

The miscellany brings together a range of genres, including dialogus, invectiva, translatio and comparatio, allowing English readers to sample a range of Humanist literary techniques alongside a cluster of translations from Greek texts, both classical and patristic. Many of the texts are focused on advice to princes and the political philosophy of princedoms, in line with the dedication to Humfrey, Duke of Gloucester, in Items 1 and 4.

While none of the three extant manuscripts is the prototype copy, textual collation shows that they are closely related. CUL, MS. Ll. i. 7 was copied directly from MS. Auct. F. 5. 26, carrying across errors in MS. Auct. F. 5. 26 before it had been checked and corrected, and the scribe of MS. Auct. F. 5. 26, William Osborne (see above), added notes (e.g. fols 19v, 28v and 113–114) and titles (fols 88, 102, 129, 143, 164 and 187) to Lambeth Palace Library, MS. 341. Notes in a small cursive script in MS. Auct. F. 5. 26 provide evidence that one person checked the transcription of all three manuscripts, adding the comment 'totum corectum' in the margin on p. 220

history.provenance: At p. 1, shelfmarks 'e Museo olim 152' and 'Ms. e Museo 119' in a 17th-century hand (both shelfmarks are present on the binding). "17" is written on p. iii and on the front board
history.acquisition: Bought with part of £5 given by Joseph Maynard, fellow of Exeter college, Oxford, in 1658 along with nine other manuscripts: Auct. D. 2. 5, MS. e Mus. 146, MS. e Mus. 111, MS. e Mus. 116, MS. e Mus. 162, MS. e Mus. 164, MS. Auct. F. 5. 28, MS. e Mus. 244 and MS. e Mus. 59

recordHist.source:
Description by Stewart J. Brookes (September 2025) based on David Rundle, 'Of Republics and Tyrants: Aspects of Quattrocento Humanist Writings and their Reception in England, c. 1400-c. 1460' (unpublished DPhil thesis, University of Oxford, 1997), pp. 434-441, with kind permission of the author. With additional reference to published literature as cited. Decoration, localization and date follow Pächt and Alexander (1973). Previously described in the Summary Catalogue (1937)
Summary Catalogue, Vol. 2, part 2, p. 704

surrogates.bibl: Black-and-white detail of pp. x and 93 in David Rundle, 'The Playpen: Reform, Experimentation and the Memory of Humfrey, Duke of Gloucester in the Registry of the University of Oxford', in Books and Bookmen in Early Modern Britain: Essays Presented to James P. Carley, ed. by James Willoughby and Jeremy Catto (Toronto: Pontifical Institute of Mediaeval Studies, 2018), pp. 18 and 39

revisionDesc.change: Description revised to incorporate information from David Rundle, 'Of Republics and Tyrants' (Oxford, 1997) and other sources, as cited, and the Summary Catalogue (1937)
